case_name: Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd. v. Respondents

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 96 of 1959 was heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 96 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated August 19, 1957 in Criminal Revision No. 1577 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1577 of 1956, arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Calcutta High Court judgment arose from Magistrate First Class at Krishnagar, Nadia judgment dated August 3, 1956 in G.R. Case No. 69 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated August 3, 1956, of the Magistrate, First Class, at Krishnagar, Nadia, in G. R. Case No. 69 of 1954.

facts.text: Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd. is incorporated under Indian Companies Act and manufactures sugar at Plassey, Nadia.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd., Calcutta, is a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act and carries on the business of manufacturing sugar which is an essential commodity in its factory at Plassey in the District of Nadia.

facts.text: Appellant declared public utility service on October 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared a public utility service by a notification duly issued in that behalf on October 8, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant employs about 545 permanent men and 703 seasonal men excluding casual labourers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant employs in its business about 545 permanent men and 703 seasonal men excluding casual labourers.

facts.text: Majority of workmen belong to Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Employees Union.

anchor.surface_text: A majority of the workmen employed by the appellant belong to the Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Employees Union hereinafter called the Employees Union

facts.text: Minority of workmen belong to Ramnagar Sugar Mill Workers Union.

anchor.surface_text: , whereas a minority of workmen belong to the rival Union called Ramnagar Sugar Mill Workers Union hereinafter called the Workers Union.

facts.text: Workers Union presented charter of demands on December 9, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on December 9, 1953, the Workers Union presented a charter of demands to the appellant.

facts.text: Employees Union presented charter of demands on January 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a similar charter of demands by the Employees Union on January 20,1954.

facts.text: Workers Union served notice of strike on appellant on January 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day the Workers Union served a notice of strike on the appellant.

facts.text: Meeting held before Conciliation Officer on February 1, 1954, attended by Employees Union and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On February 1, 1954, a meeting was held before the Conciliation Officer which was attended by the Employees Union and the appellant.

facts.text: Notice of the February 1 meeting served on Workers Union.

anchor.surface_text: A notice of the said meeting had been served on the Workers Union as well.

facts.text: On February 2, 1954, appellant suggested separate discussions with two unions to conciliation officer, but Workers Union objected.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2,1954, the appellant suggested to the conciliation officer that it should discuss the matter separately with the representatives of the two Unions but to this suggestion the Workers Union took an objection.

facts.text: Workers Union informed conciliation officer on February 2, 1954 that conciliation had failed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the said Union informed the conciliation officer that it assumed that the conciliation had failed.

facts.text: Conciliation officer sent failure report under s.12(4) on February 3, 1954 regarding Workers Union only.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently on February 3, 1954, the conciliation officer sent his report under s. 12, sub-s. (4) of the Act about the failure of conciliation with the Workers Union only.

facts.text: Appellant and Employees Union arrived at settlement on February 25, 1954, recorded in memo signed by both.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1954, the appellant and the Employees Union arrived at a settlement, and it was recorded in the form of a memo of settlement which was duly signed by both the parties.

facts.text: Workers Union commenced strike on February 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, on February 13, 1954, the Workers Union commenced a strike.

facts.text: Criminal complaint filed against eleven respondents under s.11 West Bengal Security Act, XIX of 1950 due to strike.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this strike a criminal complaint was filed against the eleven respondents under s.11 of the West Bengal Security Act, XIX of 1950, and a charge was subsequently framed against them.

facts.text: Charge against respondents: on or about February 13, 1954 at Plassey committed subversive acts impeding work of Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd., public utility concern.

anchor.surface_text: The case as formulated in the charge against the said respondents was that on or about February 13, 1954, at Plassey each one of them did commit subversive acts which were intended or likely to impede, delay or restrict the work of Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co. Ltd., which was a public utility concern for production of sugar, an essential commodity.

facts.text: Respondents pleaded not guilty, arguing strike was not illegal; not denied they went on strike February 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents pleaded not guilty to the charge substantially on the ground that the strike in question was not illegal. It was not denied that they had gone on strike on February 13, 1954

facts.text: Magistrate acquitted respondents on ground strike not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned magistrate upheld the respondents plea and acquitted the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant filed revisional application before Calcutta High Court challenging acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the correctness of the said order of acquittal by preferring a revisional application before the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed revisional application, held strike not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Its revisional application, however, failed since the High Court held that the strike was not illegal and agreed with the conclusion of the trial magistrate.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for a certificate before the said High Court but its application was dismissed. Then the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court

facts.text: Workers Union left conciliation proceedings on February 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contend that the Workers Union to which they belonged had left the conciliation proceedings on February 2,1954,

facts.text: Conciliation officer submitted failure report on February 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and that in fact the conciliation officer had submitted his failure report to that effect on February 3, 1954

facts.text: Appellant contends conciliation with Employees Union continued until February 25, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellant contends that conciliation proceedings with the Employees Union continued until February 25, 1954,

facts.text: Supreme Court held strike illegal under s.22(1)(d) due to pendency of conciliation with Employees Union.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the pendency of the conciliation proceedings between the appellant and the Employees Union attracts the provisions of s. 22 1 d to the strike in question and makes the said strike illegal under s. 24 1 1 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside acquittal and convicted respondents under s.11 West Bengal Security Act.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly set aside the order of acquittal passed by the High Court in favour of the respondents and convict them of the offence charged.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1957, of the Calcutta High Court

issues.text: short question about the construction and effect of the provisions of s. 22 1 d of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the construction and effect of the provisions of s. 22 1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 14 of 1947,  hereinafter called the Act . The appellant, Ramnagar Cane Sugar Co.

issues.text: whether the strike in question is an illegal strike under s. 24 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: That is why the only question which arises for our decision is whether the strike in question is an illegal strike under s. 24 of the Act. Section 24 of tile Act provides, inter alia, that a strike shall be illegal if it is companymenced

issues.text: Was any conciliation proceeding pending between the appellant and the respondents at the relevant time ?

anchor.surface_text: If a strike is declared in a public utility service during the pendency of a conciliation proceeding it is illegal. Was any conciliation proceeding pending between the appellant and the respondents at the relevant time ? That is the question

issues.text: in coming to the conclusion that the strike in question was not illegal the Courts below have misconstrued the provisions of s. 22 1 d of the Act

anchor.surface_text: the only point which is raised on its behalf before us is that in coming to the conclusion that the strike in question was not illegal the Courts below have misconstrued the provisions of s. 22 1  d  of the Act.

issues.text: if the impugned strike is held to be illegal it would constitute a subversive act as defined by s. 2 9 e of the West Bengal Security Act

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that if the impugned strike is held to be illegal it would constitute a subversive act as defined by s. 2 9  e  of the West Bengal Security Act. This position has been accepted in the courts below.

holdings.text: the pendency of the conciliation proceedings between the appellant and the Employees Union attracts the provisions of s. 22(1)(d) to the strike in question and makes the said strike illegal under s. 24(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the pendency of the conciliation proceedings between the appellant and the Employees Union attracts the provisions of s. 22 1 d to the strike in question and makes the said strike illegal under s. 24 1 1 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pendency of conciliation with Employees Union continued until settlement on Feb 25; common demands; binds all per s.18(3)(d); applies s.22(1)(d) and s.24

holdings.text: s.22(1)(d) 'pendency of any conciliation proceedings' must be construed to mean any conciliation proceedings which may lead to a settlement binding all workmen concerned

anchor.surface_text: When the said provision refers to the pendency of any conciliation proceedings it must reasonably be construed to mean any conciliation proceedings which may lead to a settlement before the conciliation officer and which settlement may bind all the workmen concerned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/purposive construction consistent with s.18(3)(d) binding effect and Act's policy for industrial peace; analogy to precedents on s.19(6), s.33(1)(a)

holdings.text: Settlement in conciliation proceedings binds all workmen in the establishment per s.18(3)(d), regardless of union membership

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 3  d  makes it clear that, where a party referred to in cl.  a  or  b  is composed of workmen, all persons who were employed in the establishment or part of the establishment,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.18(3)(d); settlement on Feb 25 binds respondents even if in rival union

holdings.text: Charter of demands by both unions cover all employees, not limited to one section; represent demands of whole body of workmen
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviewed charters; benefits accrue to all workmen; settlement benefited both unions' members

holdings.text: Courts below erred in putting unduly narrow construction on s.22(1)(d)
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconstrued scope of 'any conciliation proceedings'; ignored binding effect on all workmen

holdings.text: Illegal strike constitutes subversive activity under s.2(9)(e) West Bengal Security Act, punishable under s.11

anchor.surface_text: If the strike is illegal it follows that the respondents have taken part in a subversive activity as defined by s. 2 9  e  of the West Bengal Security Act and as such have committed an offence punishable under s. 11 of the said Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per definition and Explanation II; position accepted below

holdings.text: Set aside High Court order of acquittal; convict respondents of offence under s.11 West Bengal Security Act

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly set aside the order of acquittal passed by the High Court in favour of the respondents and convict them of the offence charged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of illegal strike and subversive act finding

holdings.text: If conciliation confined to specific demands for specified class, other workmen not bound (hypothetical)
